org.jtrim2.image.async

Class UriImageIOQuery

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim2.image.async.UriImageIOQuery
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AsyncDataQuery<URI,ImageResult>

    public final class UriImageIOQuery
extends Object
implements AsyncDataQuery<URI,ImageResult>
    Defines an AsyncDataQuery which is able to retrieve images based on an URI. The URI is specified as an input to the query. To actually retrieve the image file from the external source, the URL class is used, therefore UriImageIOQuery is able to retrieve any image which the URL class can. To load the image, the ImageIO library of Java is used and therefore the meta data of the retrieved image is a JavaIIOMetaData.

    This implementation completely relies on the InputStreamImageLink to retrieve images.

    Thread safety

    The methods of this class are safe to be accessed by multiple threads concurrently.

    Synchronization transparency

    The methods of this class are not synchronization transparent.
    See Also:
    InputStreamImageLink

    • Constructor Detail

      • UriImageIOQuery

        public UriImageIOQuery(TaskExecutor executor,
                       double allowedIntermediateRatio)
        Creates the UriImageIOQuery with the given properties.
        Parameters:
        executor - the executor used to actually retrieve the image. That is, the image is retrieved in a task submitted to this executor. This argument cannot be null.
        allowedIntermediateRatio - defines the approximate ratio (percentage divided by 100) of the overhead to be tolerated in order to provide intermediate images. Providing too high value for this argument might decrease performance considerably. That is, the overhead defined by this argument is likely to come true. For example: Specifying 0.5 for this argument will likely increase the time needed to read the complete image to twice the needed amount. This argument should be between 0.0 and 1.0 but the actual value of this argument is not verified. Specifying less than zero is equivalent to specifying zero, while specifying more than one, is equivalent to specifying one.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the specified URI is not absolute
        NullPointerException - thrown if the specified URI is null
